titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Francis V. O'Connor Papers, 1920-2009, in the Archives of American Art AAA.oconfran
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Judy Ng
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 211289

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-10-19T16:38-0400

did.abstract: The papers of New York art historian Francis O'Connor measure 23.4 linear feet and date from 1920-2009. Found within the papers are artist and exhibition files, questionnaires, transcripts, writings, project files, and printed material that pertain to O'Connor's research and publications on the New Deal and the Federal Arts Project of the Works Progress Administration.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers were donated by Francis O'Connor to the National Collection of Fine Arts, now the Smithsonian American Art Museum, which subsequently transferred the papers, with O'Connor's permission, to the Archives of American Art in 1974. In 2010, O'Connor donated an additional 15.8 linear feet of papers to the Archives.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: Bound assemblies of periodicals were transferred to the Smithsonian Art Libraries in 2010, which retained relevant volumes and made final decisions regarding disposition of any remaining items.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: About one-third of the collection (the "NCFA Library") is available on 35 mm microfilm reels 1084-1091 at the Archives of American Art offices, and through interlibrary loan. Researchers should note that the arrangement of the papers as described in this finding aid does not reflect the order of the collection on microfilm due to reprocessing.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Materials originally donated to the NCFA Library were microfilmed onto reels 1084-1091 shortly after receipt. The collection was further processed, the addition integrated, and a finding aid prepared by Judy Ng in 2015 with funding provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Francis V. O'Connor papers, 1920-2009. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Center. Use of archival audiovisual recordings and electronic media with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice. The Artists' Questionanaires require permission from each artist before publishing, quoting, or reproducing. Contact Reference Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Francis V. O'Connor papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Francis Oâ€™Connor has retained any intellectual property rights, including copyright, he may possess. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: New York art historian and poet Francis O'Connor (1937- ) is best known for his research and writings on the New Deal art programs of the Depression and the Roosevelt Administration. O'Connor received his Ph. D. from Johns Hopkins University in 1965 and taught contemporary European and American art history at the University of Maryland from 1964 to 1970. While at Maryland, he organized the country's first comprehensive exhibition of New Deal art programs since their ending in 1943. From 1967 to 1968, he also headed a research program for the National Endowment for the Arts to analyze the effectiveness of New Deal art patronage, which eventually led to the publication of Federal Support for the Visual Arts: The New Deal and Now (1969), New Deal Art Projects: An Anthology of Memoirs (1972), Art for the Millions (1973).

In addition to his work on New Deal art patronage, throughout the 1980s and 1990s, O'Connor continued to teach and lecture at universities, consulted on federally and privately funded research projects, and published critical essays for exhibition catalogs, anthologies and academic journals. He is a member of the College Art Association, International Association of Art Critics, and founded the Association of Independent Historians of Art in 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of New York art historian Francis O'Connor measure 23.4 linear feet and date from 1920-2009. Found within the papers are artist and exhibition files, questionnaires, transcripts, writings, project files, and printed material that pertain to O'Connor's research and publications on the New Deal and the Federal Arts Project of the Works Progress Administration.

The "NCFA Library" consists of research materials collected, created, and compiled during the course of O'Connor's research project supported by the National Endowment for the Humanities for his books Federal Support for the Visual Arts (1969) and Art for the Millions (1973). Files contain administrative records, artists' files, and questionnaires and essays that document the administration of New Deal art projects. The files were collated by O'Connor into a set that remains intact.

The publications series consists of additional research and administrative materials specifically related to O'Connor's four publications on the WPA/FAP and New Deal artists: Federal Support for the Visual Arts: The New Deal and Now (1969), New Deal Art Projects: An Anthology of Memoirs (1972), Art for the Millions (1973), and Federal Art Patronage Notes (newsletter, 1974-1984).

New Deal research files are more general research materials collected by or sent to O'Connor in the course of his academic career. These include information on New Deal administrators and state specific WPA projects; photocopies of original WPA activity and reports; and New Deal scholarship, academic symposia, and conferences.

New Deal exhibitions include announcement and catalogs of contemporary New Deal art exhibitions in the U.S. from the 1960s to the 1990s. Project files are related to three publically and privately funded New Deal research projects O'Connor directed or participated in. Printed materials consists of press coverage of federal arts patronage in the United States dating from the 1960s to 2008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 6 series. There is some overlap in series reflecting O'Connor's original order.

list.item: Series 1: NCFA Library, 1920-1974 (6.7 linear feet; Boxes 1-7, OV 28)
Series 2: Publications, 1939-1985 (4.3 linear feet; Boxes 7-11, BV 25-26, OV 27)
Series 3: New Deal Research Files, 1930-2009 (5.6 linear feet; Boxes 11-16)
Series 4: New Deal Exhibitions, 1961-1997 (1.4 linear feet; Boxes 17-18)
Series 5: Project Files, 1935-1999 (2 linear feet; Boxes 18-20)
Series 6: Printed Material, 1963-2008 (3.4 linear feet; Boxes 20-24)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These materials comprise primary source documentation covering the administration of the WPA/FAP (Works Progress Administration/Federal Arts Project) and its activities in New York City and State collected or created during O'Connor's National Endowment for the Humanities' sponsored research project, Federal Support for the Visual Arts (1969), and his subsequent book, Art for the Millions (1973).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged as 4 subseries. Materials retain O'Connor's original folder headings and arrangement and were compiled as a distinct set of research materials for the National Collection of Fine Arts Libary. There is some overlap with Series 2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Administrative records consist of photocopies of documents selected from the original records of the New York WPA/FAP at the National Archives. Documents relating to the early administration of the WPA/FAP in New York (1935) are filed at the beginning of the series. All other folder headings in the series begin with January, 1936. This series includes office administrative and employee files; program policies and procedures; and artist, project, and exhibition files. O'Connor's original research notations, correspondence, and writings have also been retained within the records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Files consist of questionnaires filled out by WPA, PWAP (Public Works of Art Project), Treasury Section, and TRAP (Treasury Relief Art Project) artists for O'Connor's Federal Support for the Visual Arts: The New Deal and Now project (FSVA) dating from 1967-1969. Included in some artists' files are original artist correspondence, curriculum vitae, exhibition catalogs, and announcements. Also found are copies of WPA correspondence from the National Archives, and copies of Government Service Administration employment histories. Original research notations, and two reports drafted by O'Connor are retained within the records. Statistical data derived from the questionnaires are included in the reports.

unittitle.emph: Report on the New Deal Art Projects in NYC and State with Recommendations for Present-Day Federal Support for the Visual Arts
Profile of the WPA Federal Art Project Artist in New York with Questionnaire Coding Guides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Files are of artists, Index of American Design personnel, teachers, administrators, and supervisors employed by the FAP, TRAP, and Treasury Section divisions. These employment forms were made for O'Connor's FSVA project by the National Personnel Records Center in St. Louis. The records were compiled from microfilmed employment records and represent an effort to create a complete list of New York WPA artists and administrators. Files of individual names contain additional material on artists including original research notes, resumes, correspondence, and printed material. Printouts of employment transcript data are also included.

did.unittitle: Computer Coding Forms of Employment Histories

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Essays are by WPA artists reflecting on their experiences in the program, which were collected in 1936 by the Washington office of the WPA/FAP to be published in a national report. By 1943, plans to publish were put on hold indefinitely until the manuscript was rediscovered by O'Connor in 1968 and published under the title Art for the Millions. Several of these files also contain multiple drafts, copies, and photographs of artists intended to be published alongside their essays.

did.unittitle: Anonymous, "Florida Galleries of the Federal Art Project"
Anonymous, "What an Art Center Can Do for Phoenix"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains research files and administrative materials related to O'Connor's publications on the WPA/FAP and New Deal artists, Federal Support for the Visual Arts: The New Deal and Now (1969), New Deal Art Projects: An Anthology of Memoirs (1972), Art for the Millions (1973), and Federal Art Patronage Notes (publication, 1974-1984). Documents include correspondence with publishers, research notes, financial records, drafts, proofs, and final reports.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged as 4 subseries. Materials are arranged by document type.

list.item: 2.1: Federal Support for the Visual Arts: The New Deal and Now, 1939-1985
2.2: New Deal Art Projects: An Anthology of Memoirs, 1968-1972

unittitle.emph: Federal Support for the Visual Arts: The New Deal and Now

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, drafts, administrative records, research data, computer printouts, and final reports related to O'Connor's National Endowment sponsored project, Federal Support for the Visual Arts (FSVA). This project was an analysis to measure the effectiveness of New Deal art projects by tracing the history of the projects, surveying the subsequent careers of participating artists, and measuring the economic value of surviving artworks where possible. The project's final report was published in 1969 and references documentation collected in Series 1.1-1.3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in BV 25-26 and OV 27.

did.unittitle: Oversized Computer Printouts from Box 8, Folder 17
Oversized Coding Forms from Box 8, Folder 18

unittitle.emph: New Deal Art Projects: An Anthology of Memoirs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, book covers, index, and an interview transcript related to the book, New Deal Art Projects, which collects the memoirs of ten artists and administrators who participated in New Deal art projects. The interview transcript is an edited version of the conversation that appears in the book between Audrey McMahon, Olive Gavert, Marchal Landgren, Jacob Kainen, Belisario Contreras, and Francis O'Connor.

did.unittitle: Book Cover and Index of Namescirca 1968-1972
Interview Transcript at End of New Deal Art Projects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, drafts, research notes, and photocopies of research source material related to the book, Art for the Millions. This selection of 103 essays written by WPA/FAP artists was originally solicited by Emanuel Benson for an annual report of the FAP in 1936. The rough manuscript remained unpublished until its rediscovery by O'Connor and subsequent publication in 1973. The book references documentation collected in Series 1.4.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, American Heritage Publishing Co., Inc.
Draft, Index and Table of Contents
Research, Primary Source Document, Book Layout, circa 1939

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Administrative printing/subscription records and final print, draft, and editorial copies related to the publication, Federal Art Patronage Notes. This quarterly newsletter was edited and published by O'Connor between 1974 and 1983 and includes articles on the history of federal arts programs, currently sponsored government programs, and recently published academic research on the topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials are of New Deal research collected by or sent to O'Connor in the course of his academic career. These include photocopies of original WPA/FAP correspondence and reports; biographical material on WPA administrators; printed material and notes on scholarly conferences and symposia; final reports on the WPA/FAP; drafts and final copies of academic research by fellow scholars; and printed material on WPA/FAP state specific projects. The events subseries also contains a symposium panel discussion on 1 sound cassette.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged as 6 subseries. Materials for administrators, scholars, and states are arranged alphabetically by name. Events and reports are arranged chronologically, and research is arranged by document type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials include biographical sketches, curriculum vitae, and photographs documenting the careers of WPA/FAP administrative staff. The subseries also includes original drafts of essays written by Rosalind Browne, Robert Cronbach, Olive Gavert, Jacob Kainen, Marchal Landgren, Audrey McMahon, Lincoln Rothschild, and Joseph Solman, which were gathered by O'Connor for publication in New Deal Art Projects: An Anthology of Memoirs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material and notes for seven scholarly New Deal symposia and conferences attended by O'Connor dating from the 1970s to the 1980s. Materials include correspondence, program guides, newsletters, clippings, planning budgets, and drafts of academic papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The subseries consists of three binders of photocopies of original reports drafted by the NY WPA office regarding the Federal Art, Music, Theatre, and Writers Projects, as well as reports on other programs relating to education, exhibitions, and recreation. These comprise weekly and monthly activity records of the four most active WPA arts projects.

did.unittitle: NY WPA Administration to Washington, D.C. Office

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General correspondence and draft copies of scholarly essays sent to O'Connor from fellow New Deal researchers, including Penny Liebman's research on Art Front. The subseries also includes three original completed manuscripts: Greta Berman's doctoral dissertation on New Deal murals in New York; Laurance Hurlburt's Mexican Muralists in the United States; and William McDonald's Federal Relief Administration and the Arts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes editors' list for Art Front.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes printed material, correspondence, and general information gathered by O'Connor that relate to New Deal arts projects in Arizona, California, Connecticut, Illinois, Maryland, Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Texas, Washington, and Wyoming.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes miscellaneous printed material on New Deal programs; WPA/FAP lists, reports, and photocopies of original documents; and inventories of collection material held at research institutions.

did.unittitle: Institution, Art Commission of the City of New York
Institution, National Collection of Fine Arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcements, catalogs, and supporting press coverage of New Deal art exhibitions in the U.S. gathered by O'Connor from the 1960s to the 1990s. Many of these catalogs provide historical background for the 1943 transfer of art from WPA Federal Art Centers to art institutions across the country. The series includes additional correspondence and planning documentation for the University of Maryland's Decade of Federal Art Patronage (1966), which was curated by O'Connor.

did.unittitle: Museum of Modern Art, U.S. Government Art Projects
University of Maryland, Decade of Federal Art Patronage

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Curated by Francis O'Connor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Project files consist of correspondence and supplementary material related to three New Deal research projects O'Connor directed or participated in. These include the CETA (Comprehensive Employment Training Act) projects, a research fellowship at the Smithsonian, and a report on WPA graphic art for the private art collectors Dave and Reba Williams. The Williams research subseries also contains word processing documents on 3 floppy discs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged as 3 subseries. Materials are arranged by document type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, notes, clippings, newsletters, and booklets related to the implementation of federally funded CETA (Comprehensive Employment Training Act) projects. These materials document CETA's administration as well as O'Connor's work as a consultant for projects on both the west and east coasts during the 1970s and 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, administrative records, and research related to O'Connor's residency as a Smithsonian visiting scholar. The subseries includes a copy of his final report, Register of New Deal Art, National Collection of Fine Arts, as well as original lists, notes, and research generated during the compilation of the report.

did.unittitle: Report, Register of New Deal Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and research related to O'Connor's 1996 research project for print collectors Dave and Reba Williams. The subseries includes a copy of the final report co-written with Avis Berman, The Graphic Art Workshops of the WPA Federal Art Project, as well as research drafts, notes, and photocopies of original WPA source material.

did.unittitle: WPA/FAP Research, Economic Data and Sources

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Materials comprise of clippings, reports, press releases, and miscellaneous printed material that document the history of federal arts patronage in the United States after the New Deal. These materials were gathered by O'Connor as part of the preliminary research for an unwritten book project.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials retain O'Connor's topical and chronological arrangements.
